SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 1

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: R.J. Morton Young
Address: Mottosville, Sask. (Box 293)
Birthplace: Bemidji, Minn., too old

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? From with parents in 1879
Where did you set up housekeeping? ...............
Where had you been living before that? Bemidji, Minn., too old
For how many people did you prepare meals? Family was parents and 6 children
How far was it to your nearest store? .......... 6 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Tea, Sugar, Bread

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? "Agilis"
and from Local mill
In what quantities did you buy it? ......................
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? About 3.85
How much did you use graham flour? ............... None
Whole wheat flour? ........................................
Was flour milled locally? Yes How far away? 6 Miles What year? 1890
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ................. ?
What other grain products did you use? ............. None
Cornmeal? ................. Whole Wheat? ........ Farina? ........
Other? ..........................................................
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? ........ No
How did you grind it? ...........................................
Young, R.J. Morton
Box 293,
Moosemin, Sask.

Butter? Yes. Eggs? Yes.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Poultry, Pork, and Beef.

How did you get fresh meat? Our own killing.

How often did you get fresh meat?

How did you preserve meat? Smoked and salted it.

If so, what year was it organized?

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh.

Kinds?
3. SUGAR AND BUTTER

In what quantity did you buy milk sugar? About 5 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of milk sugar? $1.20

Was there any other brand of sugar? No

Did you buy any other brand of sugar? No

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get your supply of fresh milk in the early days?

At the farm, Mr. Redd, Redd House.

That was the name of the dairy? Yes

Did you ever go to school? Yes

Did you make butter? Yes

What kind of cheese? Cheddar

5. MEAT AND FISH

That was your main source of meat? Pork, beef, mutton.

How did you get your meat? From the store.

How often did you get fresh meat? Twice a week.

How did you preserve meat? Cured and salted.

Was there a "meat shop" in your neighborhood? Yes

If so, what year was it organized? 1920

Did you use names? Yes

For how long? 1920-1930

What part did fish play in the family diet? Fish was eaten occasionally.

Was the fish fresh, canned, or smoked? Fresh

Kind of? Salmon

Peas? Corn? Beans? Saskatoons? Other foods?

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes

And Vegetables

To what extent? Nearly our full supply

Did you make your own vinegar? No

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Most Groceries were bought in bulk and packed in paper bags at the store. Today (1953) it is nearly all packaged at the factory.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

1. Oatmeal, Yum Potatoes, Eggs, Bread and Butter - Yes
2. Boiled Potatoes, Pork or Beef, Bread or Butter - Winter - Yes
3. Fried Potatoes, Cold Meat, Yum Bread or Butter - Yes

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? 1884
Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Father, Mother, 2 Sisters, 1 Brother & myself. Now all passed on but the Writer.
